sen.j: 大安寺（だいあんじ）は、奈良県奈良市にある高野山真言宗の仏教寺院。
sen.e: Daian-ji Temple, located in Nara City, Nara prefecture, is a Buddhist temple of the Koyasan Shingon Sect.
Daian-ji Temple, located in Nara City, Nara Prefecture, is a Buddhist temple of the Koya-san Shingon Sect.
sen.cmt: prefecture→Prefecture Koyasan→Koya-san (山号○○san：ハイフンを入れました。)
sen.e: Daian-ji Temple, located in Nara City, Nara Prefecture, is a Buddhist temple of the Koya-san Shingon Sect.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 本尊は十一面観音。
sen.e: Its principal image is Eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy).
Its principal image is Eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy).
sen.cmt: OK
sen.e: Its principal image is Eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 開基（創立者）は聖徳太子と伝える。
sen.e: Its Kaiki (founder) has been reported to be.Prince Shotoku..
Its Kaiki (founder) has been said to be Prince Shotoku.
sen.cmt: Princeの前のピリオドを取りました。reported→said
sen.e: Its Kaiki (founder) has been said to be Prince Shotoku.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 南都七大寺の1つに数えられ、奈良時代には東大寺、興福寺と並ぶ大寺であった。
sen.e: The temple, counted as one of the Seven Great Temples of Nara, was as large as in scale and ranked with Todai-ji Temple and Kofuku-ji Temple.
The temple, counted as one of the Seven Great Temples, was a big temple comparable to Nara Todai-ji Temple and Kofuku-ji Temple in size.
sen.cmt: 構文少し変えました。
sen.e: The temple, counted as one of the Seven Great Temples, was a big temple comparable to Nara Todai-ji Temple and Kofuku-ji Temple in size.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 奈良時代の大安寺は東西2基の七重塔をはじめとする大伽藍を有し、東大寺、興福寺と並ぶ大寺院であった。
sen.e: In the Nara period, Daian-ji Temple had large temple buildings, including two east and west seven-storied pagodas, and was as large as in scale and ranked with Todai-ji Temple and Kofuku-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In the Nara period, Daian-ji Temple, which had a large complex with various buildings, including two seven-storied pagodas in the east and in the west, was a huge temple comparable to Todai-ji Temple and Kofuku-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 構文変えました。
sen.e: In the Nara period, Daian-ji Temple, which had a large complex with various buildings, including two seven-storied pagodas in the east and in the west, was a huge temple comparable to Todai-ji Temple and Kofuku-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 「南大寺」の別称があった。
sen.e: It was also named "Nandaiji."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Its another name was 'Nandai-ji' Temple.
sen.cmt: 構文変えました。
sen.e: Its another name was 'Nandai-ji' Temple.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 南都七大寺のなかでも、七重塔が建っていたのは東大寺と大安寺のみである。
sen.e: Only Todai-ji Temple and Daian-ji Temple among Seven Great Temples of Nara had a seven-storied pagoda..
Among the Seven Great Temples of Nara, only Todai-ji Temple and Daian-ji Temple had a seven-storied pagoda.
sen.cmt: 構文変えました。
sen.e: Among the Seven Great Temples of Nara, only Todai-ji Temple and Daian-ji Temple had a seven-storied pagoda.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 奈良時代の大安寺には、東大寺大仏開眼の導師を務めたインド僧・菩提僊那をはじめ歴史上著名な僧が在籍した。
sen.e: Daian-ji Temple in the Nara period had many historically noted monks, including Bodai Senna from India, who served as doshi (Lead Chanter) in the kaigan (eye-opening) of Great Buddha of Todai-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Daian-ji Temple in the Nara period had many historically noted monks, including Bodai Senna from India who served as doshi (Lead Chanter) in the kaigan ceremony (eye-opening) of Great Buddha of Todai-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: the kaigan (eye-opening) of Great Buddha of Todai-ji Temple →the kaigan ceremony (eye-opening) of Great Buddha of Todai-ji Temple..
sen.e: Daian-ji Temple in the Nara period had many historically noted monks, including Bodai Senna from India who served as doshi (Lead Chanter) in the kaigan ceremony (eye-opening) of Great Buddha of Todai-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 日本仏教史上重要な役割を果たした寺院であった。
sen.e: It played an important role in Japanese History of Buddhism.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The temple played an important role in Japanese history of Buddhism.
sen.cmt: It→The templeHistory→history
sen.e: The temple played an important role in Japanese history of Buddhism.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: しかし、平安時代以後は徐々に衰退した。
sen.e: However, it gradually fell into a decline in and after the Heian period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, it gradually fell into a decline after the Heian period.
sen.cmt: in and after→after
sen.e: However, it gradually fell into a decline after the Heian period.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 寛仁元年（1017年）の火災で主要堂塔を焼失して以後は、かつての隆盛を回復することはなかった。
sen.e: After its principle doto (temple and pagoda) was burnt down in a fire in 1017, it never recovered its past prosperity.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: After its principle buildings and pagoda were burnt down in a fire in 1017, it never recovered its past prosperity.
sen.cmt: doto (temple and pagoda) was →temples and pagoda were
sen.e: After its principle buildings and pagoda were burnt down in a fire in 1017, it never recovered its past prosperity.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 現存する大安寺の堂宇はいずれも近世末～近代の再建であり、規模も著しく縮小している。
sen.e: The existing temple buildings were all rebuilt in and after the end of Edo Period, with its scale being significantly reduced.
The existing temple buildings were all rebuilt in and after the end of Edo Period on an extremely reduced size
sen.cmt: with its scale being significantly reduced→on an extremely reduced size
sen.e: The existing temple buildings were all rebuilt in and after the end of Edo Period on an extremely reduced size
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 奈良時代にさかのぼる遺品としては、8世紀末頃の制作と思われる木彫仏9体が残るのみである。
sen.e: There remain only 9 wooden Buddhas, which considered to have been built around the end of the 8th century, as its remains going back to the Nara period.
The remains that date back to the Nara period are only nine wooden statue of Buddhas, which are considered to have been built around the end of the 8th century.
sen.cmt: 構文変えました。9→nine
sen.e: The remains that date back to the Nara period are only nine wooden statue of Buddhas, which are considered to have been built around the end of the 8th century.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

tit.cmt: 指示書に従い表記しました：Kudaradai-ji

sen.j: 大安寺の歴史については、正史『日本書紀』『続日本紀』の記述のほか、天平19年（747年）作成の「大安寺伽藍縁起并流記資材帳」（だいあんじがらんえんぎ ならびに るきしざいちょう）が主なよりどころとなっている。
sen.e: The history of Daian-ji Temple mainly relies on the descriptions of official history books "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) and Shoku Nihongi' (Chronicle of Japan Continued) as well as "Daian-ji Garan Engi narabini Ruki Shizai Cho" (The notebook of the history of Daian-ji Temple, and the record of the materials.) compiled in 747.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The history of Daian-ji Temple mainly relies on the descriptions of official history books, "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) and Shoku Nihongi' (Chronicle of Japan Continued), as well as the temple's construction records, "Daian-ji Garan Engi narabini Ruki Shizai Cho" (The notebook of the history of Daian-ji Temple and the record of the materials.) compiled in 747.
sen.cmt: as well as→, as well as the temple's construction records,
sen.e: The history of Daian-ji Temple mainly relies on the descriptions of official history books, "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) and Shoku Nihongi' (Chronicle of Japan Continued), as well as the temple's construction records, "Daian-ji Garan Engi narabini Ruki Shizai Cho" (The notebook of the history of Daian-ji Temple and the record of the materials.) compiled in 747.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: （「資材帳」の写本は奈良市・正暦寺旧蔵、国立歴史民俗博物館蔵）
sen.e: (A written copy of the "Shizai Cho" was previously owned by Shoryaku-ji Temple and now owned by National Museum of Japanese History.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: (A written copy of the "Shizai Cho" was previously owned by Shoryaku-ji Temple and now owned by National Museum of Japanese History.
sen.cmt: OK
sen.e: (A written copy of the "Shizai Cho" was previously owned by Shoryaku-ji Temple and now owned by National Museum of Japanese History.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 「資材帳」によれば、大安寺の起源は聖徳太子が今の奈良県大和郡山市に建てた熊凝精舎（くまごりしょうじゃ）であるという。
sen.e: The "Shizai Cho" describes that Daian-ji Temple is originated from Kumagori shoja Temple founded by Prince Shotoku in the present-day Yamatokoriyama City Nara Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The "Shizai Cho" describes that Daian-ji Temple is originated from a Buddhist monastery, Kumagori-shoja founded by Prince Shotoku in present Yamatokoriyama City, Nara Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 熊凝精舎（くまごりしょうじゃ）：Kumagori shoja Temple→a Buddhist monastery, Kumagori-shoja としました。以下ではTempleと区別するため、Kumagori-shoja Monasteryとしました。present-day→present
sen.e: The "Shizai Cho" describes that Daian-ji Temple is originated from a Buddhist monastery, Kumagori-shoja founded by Prince Shotoku in present Yamatokoriyama City, Nara Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: またこれが移転して、「百済大寺」（くだらのおおてら、くだらだいじ）、「高市大寺」（たけちのおおてら、たけちだいじ）、「大官大寺」（だいかんだいじ）と改称を繰り返した。
sen.e: Also its name was repeatedly changed to "Kudara daiji Temple," "Takechi Daiji Temple," and "Daikandai-ji Temple," every time it was moved, and it was finally given the name of "Daian-ji Temple" with the Transferring of the national capital to Heijo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Every time the temple was moved, its name was repeatedly changed to 'Kudara daiji Temple,' 'Takechidai-ji Temple,' and 'Daikandai-ji Temple,' and following the relocation of the national capital to Heijo (present Nara City), the was moved to the new capital and established as 'Daian-ji Temple.'
sen.cmt: 構文を変えました。
sen.e: Every time the temple was relocated, its name was changed repeatedly to 'Kudaradai-ji Temple,' 'Takechidai-ji Temple,' and then 'Daikandai-ji Temple.'
sen.cmt: the→it一原文一訳文の例外処理再三にわたって、という意味を持っているので repeatedly を追加しました。

sen.j: 平城京遷都とともに寺も新都へ移転して「大安寺」となったという。
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: And following the relocation of the national capital to Heijo (present Nara City), it was moved to the new capital and renamed as 'Daian-ji Temple.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理

sen.j: 「資材帳」によれば、大安寺の起源は聖徳太子が建てた熊凝精舎であった。
sen.e: The "Shizai Cho" describes that Daian-ji Temple is originated from Kumagori shoja Temple built by Prince Shotoku.
The "Shizai Cho" describes that Daian-ji Temple is originated from Kumagori-shoja Monastery built by Prince Shotoku.
sen.cmt: Kumagori shoja Temple→Kumagori-shoja Monastery
sen.e: The "Shizai Cho" describes that Daian-ji Temple is originated from Kumagori-shoja Monastery built by Prince Shotoku.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 病床にあった聖徳太子は、見舞いに来た田村皇子（のちの舒明天皇）に、熊凝精舎を本格的な寺院にすべきことを告げたという。
sen.e: Prince Shotoku on his sickbed is said to have advised Prince Tamura (later Emperor Jomei), when the prince visited him, to make Kumagori shoja Temple a full-scale temple.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It is said that Prince Shotoku on his sickbed ordered Prince Tamura (later Emperor Jomei), when the prince visited him, to promote Kumagori-shoja Monastery to a full-scale temple.
sen.cmt: 構文を変えました。
sen.e: It is said that Prince Shotoku on his sickbed ordered Prince Tamura (later Emperor Jomei) who came to visit him to promote Kumagori-shoja Monastery to a full-scale temple.
sen.cmt: 内容を修正しました。Promote には推進するという意味があるので、大丈夫だと思います。

sen.j: 太子の意思を受けた田村皇子が、即位後の舒明天皇11年（639年）、百済川のほとりに建てたのが百済大寺であるという。
sen.e: Prince Tamura executed the Prince Shotoku's will and had Kudara daiji Temple built in the vicinity of the Kudara River in 639 after he ascended the throne.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Prince Tamura fulfilled the Prince Shotoku's will and built a temple in the vicinity of the Kudara River in 639 and named it Kudara daiji Temple, after he ascended the throne.
sen.cmt: executed→fulfilled「百済川のほとりに建てたのが」がわかるような構文に変えました。
sen.e: Prince Tamura fulfilled the Prince Shotoku's will and built a temple in the vicinity of the Kudara River in 639 and named it Kudaradai-ji Temple, after he ascended the throne.
sen.cmt: Kudara daiji→Kudaradai-ji

sen.j: 熊凝精舎については、大和郡山市額田部（ぬかたべ）に現存する額安寺がその跡ともいわれるが、「大安寺資材帳」以外の奈良時代の史料にその名が見えないことから実在が疑問視されている。
sen.e: Some believe that Kumagori shoja Temple was built at the site of Kakuan-ji Temple located in Nukatabe,Yamatokoriyama City, but some consider the location as skeptical because its name is not found in any historical materials other than "the notebook of the materials of the Daian-ji Temple."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Some believe that Kumagori-shoja Monastery was built in Nukatabe, Yamatokoriyama City, on the site where Kakuan-ji Temple is currently located, but some show skepticism about the location because its name is not found in any historical materials other than "Shizai Cho of the Daian-ji Temple."
sen.cmt: 「現存する額安寺」がわかるような構文に変えました。
sen.e: Some believe that Kumagori-shoja Monastery was built in Nukatabe, Yamatokoriyama City, on the site where Kakuan-ji Temple is currently located, but some show skepticism about the location because its name is not found in any historical materials other than "Shizai Cho of the Daian-ji Temple."
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 日本仏教興隆の祖とされる聖徳太子を創立者に仮託した伝承とみるのが通説である。
sen.e: The tradition that Prince Shotoku was the founder of the temple is a commonly-believed tradition made Prince Shotoku--a forefather of the prosper of Japanese Buddhism--its founder.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It is commonly considered in the academic world that the episode was a tradition derived from a public whish to suppose that Prince Shotoku, who was believed to be the forefather of Japanese Buddhism, was also the founder of the temple..
sen.cmt: 「仮託した伝承」が分かりやすくなるよう、構文を変えました。
sen.e: It is commonly considered in the academic world that the episode was a tradition derived from a public whish to suppose that Prince Shotoku, who was believed to be the forefather of Japanese Buddhism, was also the founder of the temple..
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 一方の百済大寺については、奈良県北葛城郡広陵町に百済寺 (広陵町)という寺が現存するものの、舒明天皇との関連は明確でない。
sen.e: Meanwhile, a relationship between the Emperor Jomei and Kudara daiji Temple has not been proved, although Kudara-ji Temple (Koryo-cho) exists in Koryo-cho, Kita-Katsuragi Ward, Nara prefecture.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Meanwhile, a relationship between the Emperor Jomei and Kudara daiji Temple has not been proved, although a temple called Kudara-ji Temple (Koryo-cho) currently exists in Koryo-cho, Kita-Katsuragi Ward, Nara prefecture.
sen.cmt: という寺が現存する：Kudara-ji Temple (Koryo-cho) exists→a temple called Kudara-ji Temple (Koryo-cho) currently exists
sen.e: Regarding the Kudaradai-ji Temple, although there is a temple called Kudara-ji Temple in Koryo-cho, Kita-Katsuragi County, Nara Prefecture, a relationship between the Emperor Jomei and the temple is unknown.
sen.cmt: 内容を少し変更しました。Kita-Katsuragi Ward→Kita-Katsuragi County

sen.j: 付近に天皇建立の寺院らしき寺跡も発見されていない。
sen.e: No remains have been detected in the neighborhood that suggest a temple founded by an emperor.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: No remains that suggest the past existence of a temple founded by the emperor have been found in the neighborhood.
sen.cmt: thatで始まる関係代名詞節を少し変え位置を変えました。
sen.e: No remains that suggest the past existence of a temple founded by the emperor have been found in the neighborhood.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 1997年、奈良国立文化財研究所（現・奈良文化財研究所）は、奈良県桜井市南西部（藤原京跡の東方）にある吉備池廃寺跡が百済大寺跡と推定されるとの見解を発表した。
sen.e: In 1997, Nara National Research Institute for Cultural Properties (present-day Nara Research Institute for Cultural Properties) announced its opinion that the remains of Kibiike disused temple in the southeast of Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture (east of the site of Fujiwara-kyo) can be the site where Kudara daiji Temple once stood.

In 1997, Nara National Research Institute for Cultural Properties (present Nara Research Institute for Cultural Properties) announced its observation that the ancient site of Kibiike Temple found in the southeast of Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture (east of the site of Fujiwara-kyo) can be the site where Kudara daiji Temple once stood.
sen.cmt: opinion →observation吉備池廃寺跡：remains of Kibiike disused temple→the ancient site of Kibiike Temple
sen.e: In 1997, Nara National Research Institute for Cultural Properties (present Nara Research Institute for Cultural Properties) announced its observation that the ancient site of Kibiike Temple found in the southeast of Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture (east of the site of Fujiwara-kyo) can be the site where Kudaradai-ji Temple once stood.
sen.cmt: Kudara daiji→Kudaradai-ji

sen.j: 発掘調査の結果、吉備池廃寺は東に金堂、西に塔が建つ法隆寺式伽藍配置の寺院であったことが明らかになった。
sen.e: Its excavation revealed that Kibiike disused temple had a "Horyu-ji-style temple layout" having Kon-do Hall (main hall of a Buddhist temple) in the east and a pagoda in the west.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Its excavation revealed that Kibiike Temple had a Horyu-ji-style temple layout with Kondo (main hall) in the east and a pagoda in the west.
sen.cmt: ""取りましたhaving Kon-do Hall (main hall of a Buddhist temple)→with Kondo (main hall)
sen.e: Its excavation revealed that Kibiike Temple had a Horyu-ji-style temple layout with Kondo (main hall) in the east and a pagoda in the west.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 発掘された古瓦の様式年代からもこの寺院が舒明天皇11年（639年）に建立された百済大寺に該当する可能性は高いと見られている。
sen.e: The style and era of the excavated old roof-tiles show that this temple is highly likely to correspond to Kudara daiji Temple built in 639.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The style and period of the excavated old roof-tiles show that this temple is highly likely to correspond to Kudara daiji Temple built in 639.
sen.cmt: era →period
sen.e: Judging from the style of the excavated old roof-tiles, there is a high posibility that this temple is Kudaradai-ji Temple which was build in 639.
sen.cmt: 「様式年代」はひとつの単語なので、単純に style (様式によって年代は判定できるため) としました。内容を多少変更しました。

tit.e: Takechi Daiji Temple and Daikandai-ji Temple
tit.cmt: 指示書に従いTakechi Daiji Temple→Takechidai-ji Templeとしました。

sen.j: 『日本書紀』には、天武天皇2年（673年）12月17日に美濃王（みののおおきみ）と紀訶多麻呂（きのかたまろ）が造高市大寺司に任命されたとあり、高市大寺が今の大官大寺だとする記述がある。
sen.e: "Nihonshoki" describes that Mino no Okimi and Ki no Katamaro were appointed Office of Todai-ji Temple Construction on December 17, 673, suggesting that Takechi Daiji Temple is the present-day Daikandai-ji Temple.

"Nihonshoki" describes that Mino no Okimi and Ki no Katamaro were appointed to take Office of Todai-ji Temple Construction on December 17, 673February 1, 974 (表記の変更), suggesting that Takechidai-ji Temple is the present Daikandai-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: appointed Office→appointed to take OfficeDecember 17, 673→February 1, 974 (表記の変更)present-day→present
sen.e: "Nihonshoki" describes that Mino no Okimi and Ki no Katamaro were appointed to take Office of Todai-ji Temple Construction on December 17, 673February 1, 974 (表記の変更), suggesting that Takechidai-ji Temple is the present Daikandai-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 「大安寺資材帳」には、その同じ日に御野王（「みののおおきみ」で美濃王と同じ）と紀訶多麻呂が造寺司に任命され、このときに寺を百済の地から高市の地に移したとある。
sen.e: "The notebook of the materials of the Daian-ji Temple" describes that Mino no Okimi and Ki no Katamaro were appointed Office of Todai-ji Temple Construction on the same date, when the temple was moved from Kudara to Takechi.
sen.cmt: （「みののおおきみ」で美濃王と同じ）は、読み方のことで、英文では同じなので訳し出ししていません。
sen.e: "Shizai Cho of the Daian-ji Temple" describes that Mino no Okimi (the same pronunciation as above but written in Chinese characters) and Ki no Katamaro were appointed to take Office of Todai-ji Temple Construction on the same date, when the temple was moved from Kudara to Takechi.
sen.cmt: 初出でないのでこれまでの表記にあわせ"Shizai Cho of the Daian-ji Temple"としました。appointed Office→appointed to take Office（「みののおおきみ」で美濃王と同じ）：(the same pronunciation as above but written in Chinese characters) 加えました。
sen.e: "Shizai Cho of the Daian-ji Temple" describes that Mino no Okimi (the same pronunciation as above but written in Chinese characters) and Ki no Katamaro were appointed to take Office of Todai-ji Temple Construction on the same date, when the temple was moved from Kudara to Takechi.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 673年は天武天皇（大海人皇子）が壬申の乱に勝利した翌年であり、同天皇の父舒明天皇の三十三回忌、母斉明天皇の十三回忌にあたることが指摘されている。
sen.e: It is pointed out that the year 673 is the following year of Jinshin War won by the Emperor Tenmu and that it fell on the 32nd anniversary of the death of his father, the Emperor Jomei, and the twelfth anniversary of the death of his mother, the Empress Saime.

sen.j: 塔は方5間（初層平面の1辺に柱が6本立ち、柱間が5間あるという意味）の大規模なもので、伝承のとおり九重塔であった可能性が高い。
sen.e: The pagoda was of a large scale according to Ho-Goken (the length between pillars at the front, back, right and left sides is 5-ken and 6 pillars in each side of the first layer plane) (ken= about 1.8m) and is likely to have been nine-storied as the tradition goes.

The pagoda seems to have been a large quadrilateral structure called Ho-Goken (a structure in which there are six columns in each of four sides, with every intercolumnar distance of 5 ken [about 9 m] on the base layer), and it is likely to have been a nine-storied pagoda as the tradition goes.
sen.cmt: The pagoda was of a large scale according to Ho-Goken (the length between pillars at the front, back, right and left sides is 5-ken and 6 pillars in each side of the first layer plane) (ken= about 1.8m)→ The pagoda seems to have been a large quadrilateral structure called Ho-Goken (a structure in which there are six columns in each of four sides, with every intercolumnar distance of 5 ken [about 9 m] on the base layer)... have been nine-storied as the tradition goes→have been a nine-storied pagoda
sen.e: The pagoda is a large quadrilateral structure called Ho-Goken (there are six columns on each of the four sides, with a space of five ken [about nine meters] between each column on the base layer) and it is highly possible that this was a nine-story pagoda as the tradition describes.
sen.cmt: in each of→on each of thewith every intercolumnar distance of→ with a space of five ken [about nine meters] between each column

sen.j: 昭和48年（1973年）から同57年（1982年）にかけて奈良国立文化財研究所の行った発掘調査によって、寺跡からは大量の焼け土や焼けた瓦が検出され、この寺が完成後まもない頃、もしくは工事中に火災に遭ったことが判明した。
sen.e: A large amount of burnt soil and tiles were detected in an excavation conducted by Nara National Research Institute for Cultural Properties between 1973 and 1982, revealing that the temple had a fire upon completion or under construction.

A large amount of burnt soil and tiles were found in the excavation conducted by Nara National Research Institute for Cultural Properties between 1973 and 1982, revealing that the temple had a fire soon after the completion or when it was still under construction.
sen.cmt: an excavation→the excavation detected→foundupon completion or under construction→soon after the completion or when it was still under construction
sen.e: A large amount of burnt soil and tiles were found in the excavation conducted by Nara National Research Institute for Cultural Properties between 1973 and 1982, revealing that the temple had a fire soon after the completion or when it was still under construction.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.e: The chronology of excavated earthware suggested that the temple buildings were constructed from the final years of Emperor Jito and early years of Emperor Monmu (the very end of the 7th century).

Daian-ji Temple in the Nara period has many noted monks including Bodai Senna from India, Doji who had studied and stayed in Tang Dynasty of China for 16 years, and other monks who studied in foreign counties or who were naturalized.
sen.cmt: 帰化僧；returned home→who were naturalized
sen.e: Daian-ji Temple in the Nara period has many noted monks including Bodai Senna from India, Doji who had studied and stayed in Tang Dynasty of China for 16 years, and other monks who studied in foreign counties or who were naturalized.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 菩提僊那は東大寺大仏開眼の導師を務めた僧として知られる。
sen.e: Bodai Senna is known as a monk who served as doshi (Lead Chanter) in the kaigan (eye-opening) of Great Buddha of Todai-ji Temple.
Bodai Senna is known as a monk who served as doshi (Lead Chanter) in the kaigan ceremony (eye-opening) of Great Buddha of Todai-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: the kaigan (eye-opening)→the kaigan ceremony (eye-opening)
sen.e: Bodai Senna is known as a monk who served as doshi (Lead Chanter) in the kaigan ceremony (eye-opening) of Great Buddha of Todai-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 道慈は三論宗系の学僧である。
sen.e: Doji, belonging to the Sanron Sect (Madhyamika school founded originally by Nagarjuna, which was brought in from China in 625 by Ekwan and was headquartered in Horyu-ji Temple in Nara, the sect belonging to the Provisional Mahayana school) was a learned priest pursuing his studies.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Doji was a learned priest of the Sanron sect.
sen.cmt: translation 1の以下の三論宗系の説明を取りました：(Madhyamika school founded originally by Nagarjuna, which was brought in from China in 625 by Ekwan and was headquartered in Horyu-ji Temple in Nara, the sect belonging to the Provisional Mahayana school)。
sen.e: Doji was a learned priest of the Sanron sect (Madhyamika school founded originally by Nagarjuna).
sen.cmt: (Madhyamika school founded originally by Nagarjuna)の部分のみ補足しました。

sen.j: 奈良時代に護国経典として重視された新訳『金光明最勝王経』を日本にもたらすなど、上代仏教史上重要な人物である。
sen.e: He played an important role in Japanese History of Buddhism of ancient times by, for example, bringing to Japan a new translation of "Golden Light of the Most Victorious Kings Sutra," which was regarded as an important Buddhist scriptures to keep the country safe in the Nara Period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He played an important role in Japanese history of Buddhism, for example, by bringing to Japan a new translation of "Golden Light of the Most Victorious Kings Sutra," a sutra valued during the Nara Period as a Buddhist scriptures to safeguard the country in the Nara Period.
sen.cmt: Japanese History of Buddhism→Japanese history of Buddhismwhich was regarded as an important Buddhist scriptures to keep the country safe in the Heian period→ a sutra valued as a Buddhist scriptures during the Heian period to safeguard the country
sen.e: He played an important role in Japanese history of Buddhism, for example, by bringing to Japan a new translation of "Golden Light of the Most Victorious Kings Sutra," a sutra valued during the Nara Period as a Buddhist scriptures to safeguard the country in the Nara Period.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 唐僧・鑑真を日本へ招請するため唐に派遣された普照と栄叡（ようえい）、空海の師にあたる勤操（ごんそう）、最澄の師にあたる行表も大安寺の僧であった。
sen.e: Other noted monks of Daian-ji Temple included Fusho and Yoei--monks dispatched to China in the Tang Period to invite priest of Tang Jianzhen to Japan, Gonso--the master of Kukai, and Gyohyo--the master of Saicho.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The following monks served at Daian-ji Temple as well: Fusho and Yoei who were dispatched to China in the Tang period to invite Priest Tang Jianzhen to Japan, Gonso who was the master of Kukai, and Gyohyo who was the master of Saicho.
sen.cmt: 複雑だったので、構文を変えました。
sen.e: The following monks served at Daian-ji Temple as well: Fusho and Yoei who were dispatched to China in the Tang period to invite Priest Tang Jianzhen to Japan, Gonso who was the master of Kukai, and Gyohyo who was the master of Saicho.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 大安寺が日本の上代仏教の発展に果たした役割は大きかったが、都が平安京へ移ると次第に衰退した。
sen.e: Daian-ji Temple played an important role in Japanese History of Buddhism of ancient times, but it gradually fell into a decline after the capital was transferred to Heian-kyo (ancient Kyoto).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Daian-ji Temple played an important role in the ancient Japanese history of Buddhism, but it gradually fell into a decline after the capital was transferred to Heian-kyo (ancient Kyoto).
sen.cmt: Japanese History of Buddhism of ancient times→the ancient Japanese history of Buddhism
sen.e: Daian-ji Temple played an important role in the ancient Japanese history of Buddhism, but it gradually fell into a decline after the capital was transferred to Heian-kyo (ancient Kyoto).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 寛仁元年（1017年）の火災では本尊釈迦如来像と東塔を残してことごとく焼失した。
sen.e: A fire that occurred in 1017 completely burned the temple except for its principal image, Shakyanyorai-zo and the east pagoda were completely burnt down.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: A fire that occurred in 1017 completely destructed the temple except for its principal image, the statue of Shaka Nyorai, and the east pagoda.
sen.cmt: were completely burnt downを取りcompletely destructed としました。
sen.e: A fire that occurred in 1017 completely destructed the temple except for its principal image, the statue of Shaka Nyorai, and the east pagoda.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: それ以後、かつての規模を取り戻すことはなかった。
sen.e: It did not returned to what it had been in a scale after the fire.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Afterwards, it had never recovered its original magnificence.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ：「それ以後、」afterwards構文を変えました。
sen.e: Afterwards, it had never recovered its original magnificence.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 慶長元年（1596年）の地震による損害の後、近世には小堂1つを残すのみであったという。
sen.e: After it was damaged in an earthquake in 1596, only one small hall is said to have remained in the early-modern times.
It was damaged by an earthquake in 1596, and it is said that only one small hall had been left in the early-modern times.
sen.cmt: 構文を変えました。Remained→was left
sen.e: It was damaged by an earthquake in 1596, and it is said that only one small hall had been left in the early-modern times.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 大安寺の旧本尊・乾漆造釈迦如来像は「資材帳」に天智天皇発願の像と記され、名作として知られていた。
sen.e: "The notebook of the materials" describes that the former principal image of Daian-ji Temple, Shakyanyorai-zo of kanshituzo (a method of making a Buddha statue, which is made of canvas and Japanese lacquer, and inside of the statue is cavity) was a statue built at the wish of the Emperor Tenchi and known as a masterpiece.

The dried lacquer statue of Shaka Nyorai, which is registered in "Shizai Cho" as the principal image of Daian-ji Temple, was a statue built at the wish of Emperor Tenchi and known as one of the masterpieces.
sen.cmt: 構文を変えました。旧本尊：the former principal image→the principal image (文脈上formerを取りました）
sen.e: The dried lacquer statue of Shaka Nyorai, which is registered in "Shizai Cho" as the principal image of Daian-ji Temple, was a statue built at the wish of Emperor Tenchi and known as one of the masterpieces.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 平安時代末期の保延6年（1140年）に南都の諸寺を巡った大江親通の『七大寺巡礼私記』は、薬師寺の本尊像（現存、国宝）についての記述のなかで、「薬師寺の本尊像は優れた作だが、大安寺の釈迦像には及ばない」という趣旨のことを述べている。
sen.e: "Shichidaiji Junrei Shiki (Private Journal of a Pilgrimage to the Seven Great Temples)" written by Chikamichi OE, who travelled and visited temples of Nanto during the end of Heian period, describes to the effect that "the statue of principal image of Yakushi-ji Temple is an excellent work but does not match Shaka zo (statue of Shakyamuni) of Daian-ji Temple.

A travelogue "Shichidaiji Junrei Shiki (Private Journal of a Pilgrimage to the Seven Great Temples)" written by Chikamichi OE, who visited various temples in the southern capital (Nara), describes as follows: 'the principal image of Yakushi-ji Temple is an excellent work, but it is far behind from Shaka zo (statue of Buddha) of Daian-ji Temple.'
sen.cmt: 以下数箇所を変えました。A travelogueを "Shichidaiji Junrei Shiki (Private Journal of a Pilgrimage to the Seven Great Temples)" の前につけました。Nanto→the southern capital (Nara) "...but does not match Shaka zo (statue of Shakyamuni) of Daian-ji Temple.→'...but it is far behind from Shaka zo (statue of Buddha)....'
sen.e: A travelogue "Shichidaiji Junrei Shiki (Private Journal of a Pilgrimage to the Seven Great Temples)" written by Chikamichi OE, who visited various temples in the southern capital (Nara), describes as follows: 'the principal image of Yakushi-ji Temple is an excellent work, but it is far behind from Shaka zo (statue of Buddha) of Daian-ji Temple.'
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 平安時代末期に和様彫刻様式を完成させた仏師・定朝も大安寺の釈迦像を模作したことが知られている。
sen.e: It is known that Jocho, a busshi(sculptor of Buddhist Statues) who completed Japanese sculpture style at the end of Heian period, imitated the Shaka zo of Daian-ji Temple.

It is known that Jocho, a busshi (sculptor of Buddhist statues) who completed the Japanese sculptures style at the end of Heian period, also made a replica of the statue of Buddha enshrined in Daian-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: a busshi (sculptor of Buddhist Statues) →a busshi (sculptor of Buddhist statues) Japanese sculptures style→the Japanese sculptures styleimitated the Shaka zo of Daian-ji Temple→also made a replica of the statue of Buddha enshrined in
sen.e: It is known that Jocho, a busshi (sculptor of Buddhist statues) who completed the Japanese sculptures style at the end of Heian period, also made a replica of the statue of Buddha enshrined in Daian-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: この釈迦像も今は失われ、見ることができない。
sen.e: We can not see this burnt-down Shaka zo any more.
However, this statue of Buddha has lost and we can not see it.
sen.cmt: Howeverで始まる構文に変えました
sen.e: However, this statue of Buddha has lost and we can not see it.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 境内（国の史跡）には本堂、嘶堂（いななきどう）などが建つがいずれも近代の建物である。
sen.e: The buildings including the main hall and Inanagi-do standing in the precinct (a historic site designated by the state) were all modern architecture.
All the buildings including the main hall and Inanagido on the temple's ground (although the complex is designated as a national historic site) are modern constructions.
sen.cmt: All で始まる構文にしました。近代の建物：modern architecture→modern constructions
sen.e: All the buildings including the main hall and Inanagido on the temple's ground (although the complex is designated as a national historic site) are modern constructions.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 本堂-本尊十一面観音立像（重文）を安置する。
sen.e: Main hall - Honzon standing statue of eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy) (important cultural property) is enshrined.
Hondo - The main hall where the principal image, the standing statue of eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy) (Important Cultural Property) is enshrined.
sen.cmt: 構文少し変えました。Honzon→the principal imageImportant Cultural Property→Important Cultural Property
sen.e: Hondo - The main hall where the principal image, the standing statue of eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy) (Important Cultural Property) is enshrined.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 本尊は秘仏で、10-11月のみ公開される。
sen.e: The Honzon is Buddhist image normally withheld from public view but made to public only in October and November.
The principal image is a treasured Buddha and it is opened to the public only in October and November.
sen.cmt: 秘仏：treasured Buddha公開される：it is opened to the public
sen.e: The principal image is a treasured Buddha and it is opened to the public only in October and November.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 嘶堂-馬頭観音立像（重文）を安置する。
sen.e: Inanagi-do- Standing statue of Bato Kannon (Horse-headed Kannon Statue) (important cultural property) is enshrined.
Inanagido- A hall where Standing statue of Bato Kannon (Horse-headed Kannon) (important cultural property) is enshrined.
sen.cmt: 構文少し変えました。
sen.e: Inanagido- A hall where Standing statue of Bato Kannon (Horse-headed Kannon) (important cultural property) is enshrined.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 像は秘仏で、3月のみ公開される。
sen.e: The Honzon is Buddhist image normally withheld from public view but made to public only in March.
It is a treasured Buddhist image placed to the public only in March.
sen.cmt: 構文少し変えました。公開される：placed to public
sen.e: It is a treasured Buddhist image placed to the public only in March.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 讃仰殿-1963年に建てられた鉄筋コンクリート造の収蔵庫で、楊柳観音立像（重文）など7躯の木彫仏を安置する。
sen.e: Sangyo-den- It is a repository of ferro-concrete built in 1963, and 7 wooden statues including Mokuzo Yoryu Kannon Ritsuzo (The wooden image of the Kannon having the branch of a willow to eradicate illness) (important cultural property) is enshrined.

Sangyoden - It is a ferroconcrete repository built in 1963, and seven wooden statues including the Wooden standing statue of Yoryu Kannon (the Kannon having the branch of a willow to eradicate illness) (Important Cultural Property) are enshrined.
sen.cmt: Sangyo-den→Sangyodena repository of ferro-concrete→ a ferroconcrete repository 7→ sevenMokuzo Yoryu Kannon Ritsuzo (The wooden image of the Kannon having the branch of a willow to eradicate illness) → (important cultural property)→Wooden standing statue of Yoryu Kannon (the Kannon having the branch of a willow to eradicate illness)is→are
sen.e: Sangyo-den - It is a ferroconcrete repository built in 1963, and seven wooden statues including Mokuzo Yoryu Kannon Ritsuzo (The wooden image of the standing Kannon holding the branch of a willow to eradicate illness) (important cultural property) is enshrined.
sen.cmt: 内容を修正しました。

sen.j: 国指定の文化財としては、6件9躯の木彫仏がある。
sen.e: Six items and nine statues are cultural properties designated by the state.
Six items and nine statues are designated as national cultural properties.
sen.cmt: cultural properties designated by the state→designated as national cultural properties
sen.e: Six items and nine statues are designated as national cultural properties.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: これらは奈良時代末期の制作と思われるが、いずれの像も破損が多い。
sen.e: These statues beloved to have been built in the late Nara period had all many damaged portions.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: These statues believed to have been made in the late Nara period are all considerably damaged
sen.cmt: beloved→believed built →made had all many damaged portions →are all considerably damaged
sen.e: These statues believed to have been made in the late Nara period are all considerably damaged
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 各像の両腕などは大部分後補のものに変わっている。
sen.e: Arms of each statue were mostly replacements in later years.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Almost of the arms of each statue are replaced by those made in later years.
sen.cmt: All Arms→ Almost of the arms were mostly replacements→are replaced with those made
sen.e: Almost of the arms of each statue are replaced by those made in later years.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 天平19年の「大安寺資材帳」にはこれらの像に該当するものが見出されないことから、それ以後の造立と思われる。
sen.e: No descriptions on these statues are found in "the notebook of the materials of the Daian-ji Temple" in 747, suggesting that they were built later.
The fact that no descriptions on these statues are found in "Shizai Cho of the Daian-ji Temple" written in 747 suggests that they were built at a later time.
sen.cmt: The fact thatで始まる構文にしました。"the notebook of the materials of the Daian-ji Temple" in 747→"Shizai Cho of the Daian-ji Temple" written in 747suggesting →suggests later →at a later time
sen.e: The fact that no descriptions on these statues are found in "Shizai Cho of the Daian-ji Temple" written in 747 suggests that they were built at a later time.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: これらの木彫仏は作風的に唐招提寺の旧講堂仏像群との類似が指摘されている。
sen.e: It has been pointed out that these wooden statues were similar in style to a group of statues of the Kodo Hall of Toshodai-ji Temple.
It has been pointed out that these wooden statues were similar in style to the statues of the Kodo (main hall) of Toshodai-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: a group of statues of the Kodo Hall of Toshodai-ji Temple→the statues of the Kodo (main hall) of Toshodai-ji Temple
sen.e: It has been pointed out that these wooden statues were similar in style to the statues of the Kodo (main hall) of Toshodai-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 重要文化財
sen.e: Important cultural property
Important Cultural Property
sen.cmt: Cultural Propertyと語頭大文字にしました。
sen.e: Important Cultural Property
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 木造十一面観音立像-当寺の本尊。
sen.e: Wooden standing statue of eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy) - the principal image of this temple
Wooden standing statue of eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy) - the principal image of this temple
sen.cmt: this temple→the temple
sen.e: Wooden standing statue of eleven-faced Kannon (Goddess of Mercy) - the principal image of this temple
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 頭部は後世のものに変わっている。
sen.e: Its head was replaced by what was built later.
Its head was replaced by the one made later.
sen.cmt: what was built→the one made
sen.e: Its head was replaced by the one made later.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 木造馬頭観音立像-重文指定名称は「木造千手観音立像」
sen.e: Wooden standing statue of Bato Kannon (Horse-headed Kannon Statue) - designated as an important cultural property in the name of "Wooden Senju Kannon ryuzo"
Wooden standing statue of Bato Kannon (Horse-headed Kannon) - Designated as an Important Cultural Property in the name of "Wooden Senju Kannon ryuzo"
sen.cmt: (Horse-headed Kannon Statue) → (Horse-headed Kannon) important cultural property → Important Cultural Property
sen.e: Wooden standing statue of Bato Kannon (Horse-headed Kannon) - Designated as an Important Cultural Property in the name of "Wooden Senju Kannon ryuzo"
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 木造不空羂索観音立像
sen.e: Wooden standing statue of Amoghapasa (manifestation of Amalokitesvara)
Wooden standing statue of Amoghapasa (manifestation of Amalokitesvara)
sen.cmt: OK
sen.e: Wooden standing statue of Amoghapasa (manifestation of Amalokitesvara)
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 木造楊柳観音立像
sen.e: Mokuzo Yoryu Kannon Ritsuzo (The wooden image of the Kannon having the branch of a willow to eradicate illness)
Wooden standing statue of Yoryu Kannon (Kannon having the branch of a willow to eradicate illness)
sen.cmt: Mokuzo Yoryu Kannon Ritsuzo (The wooden image of the Kannon having the branch of a willow to eradicate illness)→Wooden standing statue of Yoryu Kannon (Kannon having the branch of a willow to eradicate illness)
sen.e: Wooden standing statue of Yoryu Kannon (Kannon having the branch of a willow to eradicate illness)
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 木造聖観音立像
sen.e: Wooden Sho Kannon ryuzo (wooden standing statue of Sho Kannon)
Wooden standing statue of Sho Kannon (Holy Kannon)
sen.cmt: Sho Kannon (Holy Kannon)としました。
sen.e: Wooden standing statue of Sho Kannon (Holy Kannon)
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 木造四天王立像
sen.e: Wooden standing statue of the Four Devas
Wooden standing statue of
sen.cmt: the Four Devas→the Four Heavenly Kings
sen.e: Wooden standing statue of
sen.cmt: 修正なし
